items.title: Boost Your Unity Development with ConcurrentTools-Package
items.summary: In game development, handling asynchronous tasks efficiently is crucial for maintaining smooth…
items.content_html:
In game development, handling asynchronous tasks efficiently is crucial for maintaining smooth gameplay and responsive UI interactions. Unity's built-in coroutine system is helpful, but it lacks robust support for task concurrency and thread safety.

Introduction

In game development, handling asynchronous tasks efficiently is crucial for maintaining smooth gameplay and responsive UI interactions. Unity's built-in coroutine system is helpful, but it lacks robust support for task concurrency and thread safety. That's whereÂ ConcurrentTools-PackageÂ comes inâ€”a simple yet powerful task management tool designed to help developers run tasks asynchronously, schedule delayed executions, and manage concurrency seamlessly.

Why You Need a Task Manager in Unity

Unity operates on a single-threaded model for most game logic, meaning any long-running operation can cause frame drops or unresponsiveness. Here are a few key challenges developers face:

  • Long-running tasks blocking the main thread: Calling expensive operations (like network requests) directly can freeze gameplay.
  • Lack of easy async task management: Unity coroutines don't natively supportÂ async/await, making complex task management cumbersome.
  • Thread safety issues: Background tasks can't directly interact with Unity objects, requiring a safe way to transfer data back to the main thread.

ConcurrentTools-PackageÂ solves these issues by providing a streamlined way to manage tasks safely and efficiently in Unity.

Features of ConcurrentTools-Package

  • Easy-to-use API: Run async and concurrent tasks with minimal code.
  • Delayed Task Execution: Schedule tasks to run after a specified time.
  • Main Thread Execution: Ensure background tasks interact with Unity APIs safely.
  • Timeout Handling: Prevent infinite waits by setting execution limits.
  • Concurrency Support: Execute multiple tasks without affecting performance.

How to Get Started

Installation

  1. Open Unity and navigate toÂ Package ManagerÂ (Window > Package Manager).
  2. ClickÂ Add package from git URL.
  3. Enter the repository URL and clickÂ Add.
  4. The package is now ready to use!

Basic Usage

Run a Simple Task

Want to execute a task safely on the main thread? UseÂ EnumeratorRunner.Run.

EnumeratorRunner.Run(() =>
{
    Debug.Log("Running safely on the main thread.");
});

Run an Async Task with a Callback

Run a background operation and notify when it's done.

async Task FetchData()
{
    await Task.Delay(2000); // Simulate data fetching
    Debug.Log("Data fetched successfully.");
}

EnumeratorRunner.Run(FetchData, () =>
{
    Debug.Log("Task completed.");
});

Execute a Delayed Task

Need to trigger an event after a few seconds?

EnumeratorRunner.Run(() =>
{
    Debug.Log("This runs after a 3-second delay.");
}, 3f);

Handle Tasks with Timeout

Ensure a task doesn't hang forever.

async Task<int> LongProcess()
{
    await Task.Delay(6000); // Too long!
    return 42;
}

EnumeratorRunner.Run(LongProcess, (result) =>
{
    Debug.Log($"Result: {result}");
}, 5f); // Timeout after 5 seconds

Conclusion

Managing tasks in Unity can be challenging, but withÂ ConcurrentTools-Package, you get an efficient and developer-friendly solution. Whether you need to handle async operations, execute delayed functions, or ensure smooth task execution, this tool is a game-changer.

Start usingÂ ConcurrentTools-PackageÂ today and take your Unity development to the next level!

This is my simple UnityGameEngine menu management tool and I want to share it with my friends. You can Create some Menus and switch between them and manage them at multiple layers.

Introduction

Managing menus efficiently in Unity can be challenging, especially when dealing with a single scene. To simplify this process, I createdÂ MenuView-Package, a simple and effective menu management tool for Unity Game Engine. With this tool, you can create menus, switch between them quickly using button functions, and manage them across different layers effortlessly.

Why I Created MenuView-Package

When developing games in Unity, I often found handling menus within a single scene to be cumbersome. Unityâ€™s built-in UI management system requires manual toggling of GameObjects and tracking menu states, which can lead to unstructured and inefficient code.

I createdÂ MenuView-PackageÂ to:

  • Provide aÂ structured and simple wayÂ to manage menus within a single scene.
  • Allow developers toÂ switch between menus instantlyÂ via button functions.
  • OfferÂ a reusable and scalable approachÂ to menu navigation.
  • Reduce the need forÂ manual UI state tracking.

With MenuView-Package, handling menus within a single scene becomes seamless, making it easier to maintain and extend UI systems in Unity projects.

What It Does & How It Simplifies Menu Handling

MenuView-Package provides an efficient way to create and manage multiple menus in Unity. It allows you to:

  • Create menus easilyÂ by inheriting fromÂ MenuView.
  • Switch between menus dynamicallyÂ with simple commands.
  • Manage menus across multiple layers, ensuring structured navigation.
  • Avoid redundant UI state management, as the package keeps track of the last active view.
  • Call functions in UI buttonsÂ to switch menus rapidly without extra logic.

By handling menu navigation programmatically, this tool significantly reduces UI-related complexity and ensures a smoother development process.

Getting Started

Using MenuView-Package is straightforward. Follow these steps to integrate it into your Unity project:

1. Importing the Package

To use MenuView-Package, you need to import it via the Unity Package Manager:

  • OpenÂ Unity Package Manager.
  • SelectÂ Add package from git URL: MenuView-Package
  • Enter the package URL and import it into your project.

2. Creating a Menu Script

Each menu in your game should be defined as a script inheriting fromÂ MenuView. Hereâ€™s how you can set up your menu scripts:

Example 1: Main Game Menu

Create a script namedÂ MainGameMenu.csÂ and inherit fromÂ MenuViewÂ instead ofÂ MonoBehaviour.

using MenuViews;

public class MainGameMenu : MenuView
{
    protected override void Init()
    {
        // Initialize buttons, texts, events, and more
        throw new System.NotImplementedException();
    }
    
    // Available commands:
    // ChangeCurrentView<AuthMenu>();
    // ChangeToLastView();
    // LastView { get; }
    // GetCurrentView();
}

Example 2: Authentication Menu

Similarly, create another menu script for authentication, likeÂ AuthMenu.cs:

using MenuViews;

public class AuthMenu : MenuView
{
    protected override void Init()
    {
        throw new System.NotImplementedException();
    }
}

Example 3: Settings Menu

Another common menu is a settings menu. Hereâ€™s how you can create one:

using MenuViews;

public class SettingsMenu : MenuView
{
    protected override void Init()
    {
        // Initialize settings options here
    }
}

Example 4: Pause Menu

A pause menu can be added in a similar way:

using MenuViews;

public class PauseMenu : MenuView
{
    protected override void Init()
    {
        // Initialize pause menu options here
    }
}

Managing Menus

Once your menus are set up, you can manage them using various commands:

  • ChangeCurrentView<T>()Â - Switch to a specific menu view.
  • ChangeToLastView()Â - Return to the previous menu.
  • LastViewÂ - Retrieve the last active menu.
  • GetCurrentView()Â - Get the currently active menu.
  • CloseThisView()Â - Close the current menu.
  • CloseAll()Â - Close all menus in the current layer.

How to Use in UI Buttons

One of the key features of this package is the ability to call functions in UI buttons to switch menus easily. Hereâ€™s how you can do it:

  1. Attach aÂ ButtonÂ component to your UI button.
  2. In theÂ OnClick()Â event of the button, add a function call like:
    • MainGameMenu.ChangeCurrentView<AuthMenu>();
    • AuthMenu.ChangeToLastView();

This makes switching between menus fast and seamless without writing extra logic.

Why Use MenuView-Package?

  • Easy to integrateÂ â€“ Just import the package and modify your menu scripts.
  • Simplifies menu switchingÂ â€“ No need for complex UI state management.
  • Supports multiple UI layersÂ â€“ Useful for games with deep menu structures.
  • Works within a single sceneÂ â€“ No need for scene transitions for menu changes.
  • Reduces development timeÂ â€“ Provides a streamlined approach to menu navigation.

Conclusion

MenuView-Package is a lightweight and powerful tool to handle UI menus in Unity seamlessly. Whether youâ€™re building a simple game or a complex application, this tool can help streamline your UI navigation. Feel free to try it out and share your feedback!

items.title: HEcsGravitySim: A High-Performance Gravity Simulation in Unity
items.summary: HEcsGravitySim is a multi-threaded gravity simulation using Unity's ECS and Job System…
items.content_html:
HEcsGravitySim is a multi-threaded gravity simulation using Unity's ECS and Job System for real-time performance. ğŸš€

Introduction

Gravity simulations are computationally expensive, especially when dealing with numerous objects. In this project,Â HEcsGravitySim, we tackle this challenge usingÂ Unity's ECS (Entity Component System)Â andÂ Job SystemÂ to leverage multi-threading for real-time calculations. Instead of processing thousands of gravitational interactions on a single thread, which would be highly inefficient, we distribute the computations across multiple threads for a significant performance boost.

The Problem: Gravity Calculation Bottleneck

In a naive implementation of a gravity simulation, each planet applies a force to every other planet. This results in aÂ nested loopÂ withÂ O(nÂ²) complexity, where each frame requires computing forces for every pair of planets. WithÂ 1000 planets, this means 1,000,000 force calculations per frame! Running this on a single thread would lead to severe performance issues.

The Solution: Multi-Threading and Data-Oriented Programming

To overcome this computational bottleneck, we use Unity'sÂ Data-Oriented Technology Stack (DOTS), which includes:

  • Job SystemÂ â€“ Enables multithreaded computations efficiently.
  • ECS (Entity Component System)Â â€“ Provides a high-performance, data-oriented programming model.
  • Hybrid Renderer PackageÂ â€“ Ensures optimized rendering.
  • Unity Physics (Havok Physics)Â â€“ Handles physics interactions accurately.

By structuring the simulation usingÂ ECS and Jobs, we efficiently distribute calculations across multiple CPU cores, leading to a significant boost in performance and real-time simulation capabilities.

Gravity Calculation Formula

The gravitational force between two planets is calculated using Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation:

F=Gm1m2r2F = G \frac{m_1 m_2}{r^2}

Where:

  • FF is the gravitational force,
  • GG is the gravitational constant,
  • m1,m2m_1, m_2 are the masses of the two planets,
  • rr is the distance between the two planets.

Unity Implementation Example:

float3 direction = planet2.Position - planet1.Position;
float distanceSquared = math.lengthsq(direction) + 0.0001f; // Avoid division by zero
float forceMagnitude = (G * planet1.Mass * planet2.Mass) / distanceSquared;
float3 force = math.normalize(direction) * forceMagnitude;

Project Breakdown

1.Â Random Planet Generator

  • A class that generatesÂ randomly placed planetsÂ within the simulation space.
  • Assigns each planet aÂ random velocity and mass.

2.Â Planet Component Data

  • Stores essential planet properties such as:
    • Position
    • Velocity
    • Mass

3.Â Gravity System

  • UsesÂ Entity QueryÂ to fetch all planets.
  • Executes aÂ multithreaded jobÂ each frame to calculate gravitational forces efficiently.
  • Applies forces to theÂ Velocity Component, allowing the physics engine to update positions automatically.

4.Â Job System for Parallel Processing

  • Each frame, the system:
    1. Loops over all planet entities usingÂ nested loops.
    2. Distributes the calculations across multiple CPU cores usingÂ Jobs.
    3. Applies the calculated forces toÂ update velocityÂ components.
    4. The physics engine then computes the new positions.

Performance Gains

By implementingÂ ECS and Job System, we achieve:

  • Massively improved performanceÂ due to parallel processing.
  • Real-time gravity simulationÂ with thousands of planets.
  • Efficient memory management, reducing CPU bottlenecks.
  • Smooth renderingÂ using the Hybrid Renderer package.

Conclusion

HEcsGravitySim showcases the power ofÂ Data-Oriented ProgrammingÂ in Unity, enabling efficient and scalable physics simulations. WithÂ ECS, Job System, and Unity Physics, we can simulate complex gravitational interactions at real-time speeds, even with thousands of entities.

If you're interested in high-performance game development or physics simulations, exploring Unity'sÂ DOTS ecosystemÂ is a great step forward!

Stay tuned for further improvements and optimizations! ğŸš€

Check out the source code on GitHub: HEcsGravitySim

items.content_html:
Rainy Cloud is an atmospheric 2D puzzle game born from the Brackeys Game Jam 2021.1. Created in just seven days by a small team, it blends chaos and serenity, offering a unique, emotionally charged experience that stays with players long after gameplay.

Introduction

Game jams are a breeding ground for innovation, where developers push their limits under extreme time constraints. Among the many titles born from such creative pressure,Â Rainy CloudÂ stands out as an emotionally charged, atmospheric 2D puzzle game that encapsulates both chaos and serenity. Developed during theÂ Brackeys Game Jam 2021.1, this prototype is a testament to what a small team can achieve in justÂ seven days.

A collaborative effort byÂ Hooman Jalalpoor, Mahdi Motazedi, Hesam Jalalpoor,Â andÂ Golara Mozdbar,Â Rainy CloudÂ weaves a delicate balance between urgency and calmness, delivering a gaming experience that lingers long after the screen fades to black.

The Story: A Race Against the Rising Waters

Set in a world drowning under relentless rainfall,Â Rainy CloudÂ follows the journey of a young girl and her mystical fox companion. With floodwaters steadily rising, their only hope for survival lies in scavenging materials to construct a boat before it's too late.

The gameâ€™s narrative unfolds through its environments rather than explicit storytelling. Crumbling structures, eerie silhouettes in the distance, and the ever-present sound of rain create a backdrop of desolation. Yet, within this bleak setting, hope flickers in the form of the girl and her foxâ€”an unbreakable duo navigating the chaos together.

Golara Mozdbar, the gameâ€™s designer, describes their approach:Â â€œWe wanted to reinterpret â€˜chaosâ€™ as something subtle but urgent. Instead of explosions and destruction, our chaos is the creeping inevitability of rising waters.â€

Gameplay: Teamwork and Tension

Rainy CloudÂ is more than just a puzzle gameâ€”itâ€™s a test of strategy, quick thinking, and cooperation. Players must harness the unique abilities of both the girl and the fox to navigate the perilous landscape.

Character Abilities:

  • The GirlÂ â€“ Stronger and able to move heavy objects, she can reach higher platforms and construct elements needed for the boat.
  • The FoxÂ â€“ Agile and small, the fox can squeeze through narrow gaps, activate distant switches, and even provide magical assistance.

The game seamlessly integrates these mechanics into puzzles that require players to think critically. Whether itâ€™s triggering a mechanism to unlock a new path or coordinating actions to escape rising water, every decision counts.

The ticking pressure of the flood adds an element of urgencyâ€”forcing players to balance exploration with efficiency. The result? A tense yet rewarding gameplay experience that makes every victory feel hard-earned.

Art & Sound: A Dreamlike Atmosphere

Mahdi Motazedi, the gameâ€™s artist and animator, has crafted a world that is both whimsical and melancholic. The stark contrast between the glowing fox and the dark, rain-drenched surroundings heightens the sense of isolation, while the fluid animations add a layer of realism to the characters' emotions.

The audio design, led byÂ Hesam Jalalpoor, further enhances the experience. With soft piano melodies intertwined with the ever-present sound of rain and distant thunder, the game creates an atmosphere that is at once soothing and unsettling.Â â€œWe wanted the music to reflect both the desperation and the quiet determination of our characters,â€Â Hesam explains.

The Challenge of Game Jams

Game jams demand a tight workflow, and theÂ Rainy CloudÂ team knew they had limited time to execute their vision.Â Hooman Jalalpoor, the Unity developer, emphasized the importance of prioritization:

â€œWe focused first on movement, puzzles, and the flood mechanic. Once that core loop was polished, we filled in the details with art and sound.â€

One of the team's standout achievements was implementing configurable controls, allowing players to seamlessly switch betweenÂ keyboard, mouse, and controllersâ€”a feature not often seen in jam projects.

A Short but Impactful Experience

AlthoughÂ Rainy CloudÂ is labeled aÂ prototype, it feels surprisingly complete. A single playthrough lasts just a few minutes, yet those minutes are packed with intricate puzzles, evocative visuals, and a lingering sense of urgency.

Since its launch onÂ itch.ioÂ (play here),Â Rainy CloudÂ has received praise for its emotional depth and creative interpretation of the jamâ€™s theme,Â â€œLet There Be Chaos.â€

Final Thoughts: The Beauty of Chaos

At its core,Â Rainy CloudÂ is a story about resilience, teamwork, and hope in the face of an overwhelming force. It is a reminder that even within the constraints of a game jam, beauty can emerge from chaos.

Whether youâ€™re a fan of puzzle games, indie titles, or simply appreciate thoughtful storytelling,Â Rainy CloudÂ is well worth your time.Â Dive into the storm, embrace the challenge, and uncover the magic within the rain.
